note.p: William B. Anderson's letter dated August 10, 1862 from Cincinnati and addressed to his wife Louisa is written in ink on both sides of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 10.0 inches tall (20cm by 24.5cm) and ruled with horizontal blue lines spaced about 0.75cm apart. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are clean, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears originally to have been folded once crosswise and three times lengthwise. At this writing, the ink appears dark brown and the paper off-white (cream).

projectDesc.p: The letter written by William B. Anderson to his wife Louisa on August 10 of 1862 is a fairly long letter with about 486 words; however is still much like the other letters in our collection. This particular letter, along with all but two, was composed by Anderson while in Cincinnati, OH. This letter, like many of his letters, speaks briefly about his work on the river, but mostly the letter consists of casual correspondence between Anderson and his wife. Most of Anderson’s letters follow the same outline; a quick recap of his recent work activities, the weather and river conditions as well as the status of his river boat. He then moves on to ask how his wife and their children are, he also asks about personal and financial issues back home.

The fact that most of Anderson’s letters were composed from Cincinnati and dated fairly regularly gives us a sense of his schedule and whereabouts along the Ohio River. Within each letter Anderson tells his wife what cities he has just come from and where he is headed. This schedule also helps us connect Anderson’s business as a riverboat captain to well known Civil War events. By looking at the date of each letter we are able to correlate his activity on the Ohio River with the American Civil War. In fact, this letter mentions Buffington Island. Although this letter is dated almost a year before the battle at Buffington Island (Buffington Island), it still shows how Anderson’s life on the Ohio River was directly related to the American Civil War.

Throughout the collection we also learn that being a riverboat captain is not Anderson’s only occupation. This letter does not directly reference his business back home but as with many of the letters Anderson tells his wife how to handle financial business back home. Specifically, in this letter, Anderson tells Louisa that he has requested that John Russel, a local businessman often referred to in Anderson’s letters (The Bibliographical Review, 205), was to pay his taxes.

All of these letters provide a wonderful sense of what life in the Midwest was like during the years of the Civil War and more importantly they convey the "common man's view of great events"(Smith). Anderson’s letter written to his wife on 10 August 1862 along with the other letters included in the collection should also prove interesting to business historians and students of letter writing in American culture (Hewitt)

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. For more information about TEI P4, see http://www.tei-c.org/P4X/. To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

bibl.title: Letter from William B. Anderson to his wife, Louisa, 10 August 1862.

div1.p: In this letter Anderson assures his wife that he is doing well and asks how she and the children are. He also tells her of his visit to see her mother and that he has asked John Russell (a local businessman often referred to in Anderson’s letters) to pay his taxes in his absence.
Previous letter27 July 1862 Next letter16 August 1862

Your of 7 Came to hand
today on our arrival & I was glad to hear
of your health being better and that of the
Children3 being good I have been well since
I wrote to you though have suffered by
heat Considerably we made 2 trips to
Parkersburg 4 & are bound up tomorrow again
we have had uncommon hard work to
get up have had to lighten at Buffington 5
& Blennerhassetts 6 Island & line flats & Barges
and had a good ell of work and anxiety of
mind for a little money we made between
3 and 400 Dolls last week I cannot tell what our
prospects will be this week yet but I hope
we shall not lose anything
I was down to see your mother 7 this evening
she & Ella 8 are well I did not get down
to see her last trip & it was as well for
she had gone down to South Bend 9 and
did not get up till Tuesday she says that
she enjoyed the trip and put up a
large quantity of Blackberries Fruit of all
kinds is very abundant and watter mellons
are beginning to get plenty we had some
to eat on the boat this evening that
the crew bot which were very fine
I wrote a letter to John Russell 10 and
requested him to pay my taxes I cannot
tell you when you may look for me
up as it is very uncertain when I can
go up with the Boat & I want to make
all I can out of her I will not leave
her in any bodys hands untill compelled
to by sickness or war I want you to
try to make yourself as happy as as you
Can under the circumstances I know how
you feel about this war 11 matter but you
need not to make yourself uneasy on my
account for you can rest assured that
I will try to keep out of danger as well
as I can I will be less likely to be draf
=ted by being away than I would be if
at home I am at present in part in the
government employ in the way of a transport
that is we carry a great many soldiers and
large quantitys of Gov Frt. I expect if the
water gets much lower we will not even
[get as ] far up as Parkersburg and may be
employed to Carry Gov Frt. & soldiers up
as far as Gallipolis 12 & if such should be
the case then I will be Free from the draft
I will expect a letter here when I return
which will be on this day week I will drop
you a line tomorrow before we leave and
let you know what our prospects are Kiss
all the children for me and take care of yourself
and them for me

div1.note: 1. Cincinnati is a city in southwestern Ohio that lies on the Ohio River Cincinnati, Ohio 1
2. Mary Louisa Fischgens (1837-1911) and William B. Anderson were married September 15, 1853 in Cincinnati, Ohio. History of Allegheny County 298-299
3. At the time this letter was written, W.B. Anderson and his wife Lousia had four children: William Y. Anna M, John L., and Robert History of Allegheny County 298-299

4. "Parkersburg was originally named Newport when it was laid out in the late 1700s. A section of the land in the town was laid out over land granted to Alexander Parker for his Revolutionary War service. The title conflicts between Parker and the city planners of Newport were settled in 1809 in favor of Alexander Parker's heirs. The town was renamed Parkersburg in 1810. It was chartered by the Virginia General Assembly in 1820. It was rechartered as a city in 1860. The town was the terminus of the Staunton-Parkersburg Turnpike and the Northwestern Turnpike. In 1857 the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad built a branch line to the town. The town was important as a transportation and medical center during the American Civil War. It then became a transportation hub in the gas and oil boom following that war. It is now the home of the Bureau of the Public Debt." Parkersburg, West Virginia, Wikipedia 1

5. Buffington Island is an island on the Ohio River in Jackson County, West Virginia north of Pomeroy, Ohio. Nearby in Ohio, the only battle to occur on Ohio soil during the American Civil War, the Battle of Buffington Island, took place on July 19, 1863. Buffington Island 1
6. Blennerhassetts Island is located near Belpre, Ohio. Blennerhassett's Island 1
7. Louisa Anderson's mother, Anna M. Fischgens (full name Anna Mary Woolslayer Fischgens, born 7-12-1812, died 11-25-1897) History of Allegheny County 298-299

9. Presumably Anderson is refering to South Bend Township. South Bend is located in Armstrong County, PA was established on the 17th day of April, 1867 History of Armstrong County, Pennsylvania 394-399
10. John Russel, referred to as “a prominent merchant on Liberty Street for many years” The Bibliographical Review 205
11. The American Civil War (1861–1865) American Civil War 1
12. Gallipolis is a city in Gallia County, Ohio Gallipolis, Ohio 1
13. William B. Anderson (1822-1897) History of Allegheny County 298-299
